segment.source: Customize the Start Screen
segment.target: Customize the Start Screen

segment.source: Customize the Start Screen
segment.target: Customize the Start Screen

segment.source: Customize the Start Screen
segment.target: Customize the Start Screen

segment.source: You can add your business apps to a Windows image and customize the Start screen to include them.
segment.target: You can add your business apps to a Windows image and customize the Start screen to include them.

segment.source: You can customize the Start screen for Windows 10 Enterprise, Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, or a domain-joined PC running Windows 10 Pro.
segment.target: You can customize the Start screen for Windows 10 Enterprise, Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, or a domain-joined PC running Windows 10 Pro.

segment.source: Line-of-business (LOB) Windows Store apps do not have to be certified or installed through the Windows Store.
segment.target: Line-of-business (LOB) Windows Store apps do not have to be certified or installed through the Windows Store.

segment.source: Adding apps that do not come from the Windows Store is called sideloading.
segment.target: Adding apps that do not come from the Windows Store is called sideloading.

segment.source: Sideloaded apps must be signed with a certificate that is chained to a trusted root certificate.
segment.target: Sideloaded apps must be signed with a certificate that is chained to a trusted root certificate.

segment.source: For more information about sideloading Windows Store apps, including requirements, see Sideload Apps with DISM.
segment.target: For more information about sideloading Windows Store apps, including requirements, see Sideload Apps with DISM.

segment.source: To install Windows Store apps that are not part of your business line, you must use the Windows Store.
segment.target: To install Windows Store apps that are not part of your business line, you must use the Windows Store.

segment.source: In this topic:
segment.target: In this topic:

segment.source: Use CopyProfile to preserve Start screen layout
segment.target: Use CopyProfile to preserve Start screen layout

segment.source: Copy the AppsFolderLayout.Bin file to set default Start screen layout
segment.target: Copy the AppsFolderLayout.Bin file to set default Start screen layout

segment.source: Use StartTiles settings to lay out the Start screen
segment.target: Use StartTiles settings to lay out the Start screen

segment.source: Use CopyProfile to preserve Start screen layout
segment.target: Use CopyProfile to preserve Start screen layout

segment.source: The CopyProfile method allows you to remove tiles from the Start screen, add tiles, resize tiles, and label tile groups.
segment.target: The CopyProfile method allows you to remove tiles from the Start screen, add tiles, resize tiles, and label tile groups.

segment.source: CopyProfile also lets you customize Start screen color, Start screen accent, and desktop background.
segment.target: CopyProfile also lets you customize Start screen color, Start screen accent, and desktop background.

segment.source: You can add provisioned app packages (.appx) and customize the Start screen for your Windows image before you deploy the image.
segment.target: You can add provisioned app packages (.appx) and customize the Start screen for your Windows image before you deploy the image.

segment.source: Windows apps that are added to the Windows image are called provisioned apps.
segment.target: Windows apps that are added to the Windows image are called provisioned apps.

segment.source: Provisioned apps are staged in the image and are scheduled to be installed for every user of the Windows image at first logon.
segment.target: Provisioned apps are staged in the image and are scheduled to be installed for every user of the Windows image at first logon.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If you use both the CopyProfile and StartTiles settings in your unattended answer file, CopyProfile will override the StartTiles settings.
segment.target: If you use both the CopyProfile and StartTiles settings in your unattended answer file, CopyProfile will override the StartTiles settings.

segment.source: To use the StartTiles settings on an image generated with CopyProfile, delete the appsFolderLayout.bin file from the image.
segment.target: To use the StartTiles settings on an image generated with CopyProfile, delete the appsFolderLayout.bin file from the image.

segment.source: For more information about this file, see Copy the AppsFolderLayout.Bin file to set default Start screen layout.
segment.target: For more information about this file, see Copy the AppsFolderLayout.Bin file to set default Start screen layout.

segment.source: To add apps that you can pin to the Start screen
segment.target: To add apps that you can pin to the Start screen

segment.source: Add or remove apps from the image.
segment.target: Add or remove apps from the image.

segment.source: You can mount the Windows image offline and add provisioned app packages for your business line.
segment.target: You can mount the Windows image offline and add provisioned app packages for your business line.

segment.source: Provisioned apps will install for every user of the Windows image at first logon.
segment.target: Provisioned apps will install for every user of the Windows image at first logon.

segment.source: You can also remove provisioned app packages from the Windows image, including inbox apps.
segment.target: You can also remove provisioned app packages from the Windows image, including inbox apps.

segment.source: Use the Get-AppxProvisionedPackage cmdlet for PowerShell or the Deployment Image Servicing and Management tool (DISM.exe) to get a list of Windows Store apps that are provisioned in the image and choose the apps you want to remove.
segment.target: Use the Get-AppxProvisionedPackage cmdlet for PowerShell or the Deployment Image Servicing and Management tool (DISM.exe) to get a list of Windows Store apps that are provisioned in the image and choose the apps you want to remove.

segment.source: For more information about provisioning apps, see Sideload Apps with DISM.
segment.target: For more information about provisioning apps, see Sideload Apps with DISM.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Do not use the Windows Store before you deploy the image.
segment.target: Do not use the Windows Store before you deploy the image.

segment.source: If you download apps or download app updates for any provisioned apps in the image, Sysprep will fail.
segment.target: If you download apps or download app updates for any provisioned apps in the image, Sysprep will fail.

segment.source: For more information, see Removing or Updating Windows 8 built-in Windows Store apps causes Sysprep to fail.
segment.target: For more information, see Removing or Updating Windows 8 built-in Windows Store apps causes Sysprep to fail.

segment.source: For more information about mounting a Windows image, see Mount and Modify a Windows Image Using DISM.
segment.target: For more information about mounting a Windows image, see Mount and Modify a Windows Image Using DISM.

segment.source: For more information about DISM cmdlets for PowerShell, see Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) Cmdlets in Windows PowerShell.
segment.target: For more information about DISM cmdlets for PowerShell, see Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) Cmdlets in Windows PowerShell.

segment.source: To enable the Administrator account
segment.target: To enable the Administrator account

segment.source: Deploy the image to a test computer.
segment.target: Deploy the image to a test computer.

segment.source: Apply the image to a test computer.
segment.target: Apply the image to a test computer.

segment.source: For example, at an elevated command prompt, type:
segment.target: For example, at an elevated command prompt, type:

segment.source: For more information about applying an image, see Apply Images Using DISM.
segment.target: For more information about applying an image, see Apply Images Using DISM.

segment.source: Create a test account.
segment.target: Create a test account.

segment.source: Complete the out-of-box experience (OOBE) screens to set up a new user profile.
segment.target: Complete the out-of-box experience (OOBE) screens to set up a new user profile.

segment.source: Enable sideloading.
segment.target: Enable sideloading.

segment.source: Once you have created a new user profile, you can log in to the image and enable the group policy settings for sideloading if you have not already done so.
segment.target: Once you have created a new user profile, you can log in to the image and enable the group policy settings for sideloading if you have not already done so.

segment.source: For more information, see Sideload Apps with DISM.
segment.target: For more information, see Sideload Apps with DISM.

segment.source: Enable the Administrator account.
segment.target: Enable the Administrator account.

segment.source: You can enable the Administrator account in the Windows image.
segment.target: You can enable the Administrator account in the Windows image.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: From the Start screen, type Computer.
segment.target: From the Start screen, type Computer.

segment.source: Right-click Computer in the Search results and click Manage from the app bar at the bottom of the screen.
segment.target: Right-click Computer in the Search results and click Manage from the app bar at the bottom of the screen.

segment.source: In the Computer Management window, click System ToolsLocal Users and GroupsUsersAdministrator.
segment.target: In the Computer Management window, click System ToolsLocal Users and GroupsUsersAdministrator.

segment.source: In the Administrator Properties window, deselect Account is disabled.
segment.target: In the Administrator Properties window, deselect Account is disabled.

segment.source: Set the FilterAdministratorToken registry key.
segment.target: Set the FilterAdministratorToken registry key.

segment.source: You must set the FilterAdministratorToken registry key in order to allow the Administrator account to run Windows Store apps.
segment.target: You must set the FilterAdministratorToken registry key in order to allow the Administrator account to run Windows Store apps.

segment.source: For example, at a command prompt, type:
segment.target: For example, at a command prompt, type:

segment.source: Log in as Administrator.
segment.target: Log in as Administrator.

segment.source: Log out of the test account, and log in as the Administrator.
segment.target: Log out of the test account, and log in as the Administrator.

segment.source: Now you can configure the Start screen in your Administrator account that you want to copy for every new user profile.
segment.target: Now you can configure the Start screen in your Administrator account that you want to copy for every new user profile.

segment.source: To design the Start screen
segment.target: To design the Start screen

segment.source: You can customize the Start screen for your business in many ways.
segment.target: You can customize the Start screen for your business in many ways.

segment.source: You can add tiles for your LOB apps, remove tiles, move tile groups, and label tile groups.
segment.target: You can add tiles for your LOB apps, remove tiles, move tile groups, and label tile groups.

segment.source: Pin apps to the Start screen.
segment.target: Pin apps to the Start screen.

segment.source: From the Start screen, type the name of the app.
segment.target: From the Start screen, type the name of the app.

segment.source: When the app appears in the search results view, right-click the app and then click Pin to start.
segment.target: When the app appears in the search results view, right-click the app and then click Pin to start.

segment.source: Drag tiles on the Start screen to reorder or group them.
segment.target: Drag tiles on the Start screen to reorder or group them.

segment.source: Click the magnifying glass icon in the lower-right corner of the Start menu to view the Start screen in semantic zoom.
segment.target: Click the magnifying glass icon in the lower-right corner of the Start menu to view the Start screen in semantic zoom.

segment.source: Right-click a group of apps and select Name group.
segment.target: Right-click a group of apps and select Name group.

segment.source: Specify a name for each group of apps on the Start screen.
segment.target: Specify a name for each group of apps on the Start screen.

segment.source: To set CopyProfile in an unattended answer file
segment.target: To set CopyProfile in an unattended answer file

segment.source: You can use an unattended answer file to preserve the layout of the Start screen that you designed.
segment.target: You can use an unattended answer file to preserve the layout of the Start screen that you designed.

segment.source: In the answer file, add the CopyProfile setting to the specialize pass.
segment.target: In the answer file, add the CopyProfile setting to the specialize pass.

segment.source: Create or open an answer file in Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM).
segment.target: Create or open an answer file in Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM).

segment.source: For more information, see Windows System Image Manager Technical Reference.
segment.target: For more information, see Windows System Image Manager Technical Reference.

segment.source: In the Windows Image pane, right-click amd64Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup or x86Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup, and then select Add Setting to Pass 4 specialize.
segment.target: In the Windows Image pane, right-click amd64Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup or x86Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup, and then select Add Setting to Pass 4 specialize.

segment.source: In the Answer File pane of Windows SIM, select Components4 specializeMicrosoft-Windows-Shell-Setupneutral.
segment.target: In the Answer File pane of Windows SIM, select Components4 specializeMicrosoft-Windows-Shell-Setupneutral.

segment.source: In the Properties of Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup pane, in the Settings section, set CopyProfile to true.
segment.target: In the Properties of Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup pane, in the Settings section, set CopyProfile to true.

segment.source: Example of the XML to set CopyProfile in an answer file:
segment.target: Example of the XML to set CopyProfile in an answer file:

segment.source: This example is for a computer with an x86 architecture.
segment.target: This example is for a computer with an x86 architecture.

segment.source: To generalize and deploy the image
segment.target: To generalize and deploy the image

segment.source: You can clean up the image before you deploy it.
segment.target: You can clean up the image before you deploy it.

segment.source: You must also generalize the image before you can deploy it to additional computers.
segment.target: You must also generalize the image before you can deploy it to additional computers.

segment.source: If you do not generalize the image, the image may become unusable.
segment.target: If you do not generalize the image, the image may become unusable.

segment.source: Note Verify that all app packages in the image are provisioned.
segment.target: Note Verify that all app packages in the image are provisioned.

segment.source: Remove any non-provisioned app packages before running sysprep.
segment.target: Remove any non-provisioned app packages before running sysprep.

segment.source: For example, in PowerShell, you can remove all non-provisioned app packages:
segment.target: For example, in PowerShell, you can remove all non-provisioned app packages:

segment.source: When you generalize an image by using the Sysprep tool, hardware-specific settings are removed from the image.
segment.target: When you generalize an image by using the Sysprep tool, hardware-specific settings are removed from the image.

segment.source: Specify the unattended answer file with the CopyProfile setting to preserve the customized Start screen layout that you created.
segment.target: Specify the unattended answer file with the CopyProfile setting to preserve the customized Start screen layout that you created.

segment.source: To clean up the image
segment.target: To clean up the image

segment.source: Delete the test account.
segment.target: Delete the test account.

segment.source: You can delete the user profile you used to enable the Administrator account if you do not want to include it in the Windows image you deploy in your enterprise.
segment.target: You can delete the user profile you used to enable the Administrator account if you do not want to include it in the Windows image you deploy in your enterprise.

segment.source: For more information, see How to Disable and Delete User Profiles.
segment.target: For more information, see How to Disable and Delete User Profiles.

segment.source: Reset the registry key.
segment.target: Reset the registry key.

segment.source: You should reset the FilterAdministratorToken registry key before you deploy the image.
segment.target: You should reset the FilterAdministratorToken registry key before you deploy the image.

segment.source: For example, at a command prompt, type:
segment.target: For example, at a command prompt, type:

segment.source: To generalize the image
segment.target: To generalize the image

segment.source: At an elevated command prompt, run Sysprep and specify the location of the unattended answer file.
segment.target: At an elevated command prompt, run Sysprep and specify the location of the unattended answer file.

segment.source: For example, type:
segment.target: For example, type:

segment.source: You can capture the generalized image using the DISM tool and deploy it to multiple computers.
segment.target: You can capture the generalized image using the DISM tool and deploy it to multiple computers.

segment.source: For more information, see the DISM - Deployment Image Servicing and Management Technical Reference for Windows.
segment.target: For more information, see the DISM - Deployment Image Servicing and Management Technical Reference for Windows.

segment.source: When you apply the image, you must use the customized Unattend.xml file with CopyProfile set to true in order to preserve the changes to the Start screen.
segment.target: When you apply the image, you must use the customized Unattend.xml file with CopyProfile set to true in order to preserve the changes to the Start screen.

segment.source: Copy the AppsFolderLayout.Bin file to set default Start screen layout
segment.target: Copy the AppsFolderLayout.Bin file to set default Start screen layout

segment.source: You can customize the Start screen for Windows 10 Enterprise, Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, or a domain-joined PC running Windows 10 Pro by copying a customized AppsFolderLayout.bin file to the default user profile in the Windows image.
segment.target: You can customize the Start screen for Windows 10 Enterprise, Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, or a domain-joined PC running Windows 10 Pro by copying a customized AppsFolderLayout.bin file to the default user profile in the Windows image.

segment.source: In this method, you deploy your image to a test computer, create a user profile, visually design the Start screen, and copy that design back into your master image.
segment.target: In this method, you deploy your image to a test computer, create a user profile, visually design the Start screen, and copy that design back into your master image.

segment.source: You can remove app tiles from the Start screen, add tiles for Windows apps, resize tiles, and label tile groups.
segment.target: You can remove app tiles from the Start screen, add tiles for Windows apps, resize tiles, and label tile groups.

segment.source: On a reference PC running Windows 10 Enterprise, Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, or a domain-joined PC running Windows 10 Pro, customize the Start screen.
segment.target: On a reference PC running Windows 10 Enterprise, Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, or a domain-joined PC running Windows 10 Pro, customize the Start screen.

segment.source: Run the Sysprep tool to initialize system cleanup.
segment.target: Run the Sysprep tool to initialize system cleanup.

segment.source: For example, from a command prompt type:
segment.target: For example, from a command prompt type:

segment.source: Select Enter System Audit Mode and Reboot and click OK.
segment.target: Select Enter System Audit Mode and Reboot and click OK.

segment.source: Copy the AppsFolderLayout.bin file from the user profile with the customized Start screen.
segment.target: Copy the AppsFolderLayout.bin file from the user profile with the customized Start screen.

segment.source: For example, to copy the Start screen customizations for “TestProfile” to a USB flash drive, at a command prompt, type:
segment.target: For example, to copy the Start screen customizations for “TestProfile” to a USB flash drive, at a command prompt, type:

segment.source: In the mounted or online Windows image that you want to add the Start screen customizations to, copy the AppsFolderLayout.bin file to the default user profile.
segment.target: In the mounted or online Windows image that you want to add the Start screen customizations to, copy the AppsFolderLayout.bin file to the default user profile.

segment.source: For example, at a command prompt, type:
segment.target: For example, at a command prompt, type:

segment.source: For more information about mounting an offline Windows image for servicing, see Mount and Modify a Windows Image Using DISM.
segment.target: For more information about mounting an offline Windows image for servicing, see Mount and Modify a Windows Image Using DISM.

segment.source: The Start screen customizations will be applied to every new user profile that is created.
segment.target: The Start screen customizations will be applied to every new user profile that is created.

segment.source: The AppsFolderLayout.bin file will be overwritten if you generalize the image.
segment.target: The AppsFolderLayout.bin file will be overwritten if you generalize the image.

segment.source: You must add the file after you have generalized the image.
segment.target: You must add the file after you have generalized the image.

segment.source: Use StartTiles settings to lay out the Start screen
segment.target: Use StartTiles settings to lay out the Start screen

segment.source: You can use settings in an unattended answer file to specify how the app tiles display on the Start screen.
segment.target: You can use settings in an unattended answer file to specify how the app tiles display on the Start screen.

segment.source: You can’t remove tiles from the Start screen or label groups using unattend settings, but you can specify how tiles for 24 installed apps are displayed using the StartTiles settings.
segment.target: You can’t remove tiles from the Start screen or label groups using unattend settings, but you can specify how tiles for 24 installed apps are displayed using the StartTiles settings.

segment.source: Each of the settings maps to a fixed position in the Start screen templates, and these positions vary according to the destination PC's screen size, resolution, and DPI.
segment.target: Each of the settings maps to a fixed position in the Start screen templates, and these positions vary according to the destination PC's screen size, resolution, and DPI.

segment.source: Each setting specifies whether the tile is a wide tile or a square tile for an app, or if it's a square tile for a desktop app.
segment.target: Each setting specifies whether the tile is a wide tile or a square tile for an app, or if it's a square tile for a desktop app.

segment.source: Note If you use both the CopyProfile and StartTiles settings in your unattended answer file, CopyProfile will override the StartTiles settings.
segment.target: Note If you use both the CopyProfile and StartTiles settings in your unattended answer file, CopyProfile will override the StartTiles settings.

segment.source: Get the AppID of your LOB apps.
segment.target: Get the AppID of your LOB apps.

segment.source: To use the unattend settings, you need the specific AppID string that is associated with an installed app.
segment.target: To use the unattend settings, you need the specific AppID string that is associated with an installed app.

segment.source: You can create this string by using the get-AppxPackage cmdlet in Windows PowerShell.
segment.target: You can create this string by using the get-AppxPackage cmdlet in Windows PowerShell.

segment.source: The following example shows how to get the AppID string to use in the unattend settings for every app that is already installed on the computer:
segment.target: The following example shows how to get the AppID string to use in the unattend settings for every app that is already installed on the computer:

segment.source: Open an answer file.
segment.target: Open an answer file.

segment.source: Create or open an answer file in Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM).
segment.target: Create or open an answer file in Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM).

segment.source: For more information, see Windows System Image Manager Technical Reference.
segment.target: For more information, see Windows System Image Manager Technical Reference.

segment.source: Add StartTiles settings to your answer file.
segment.target: Add StartTiles settings to your answer file.

segment.source: Use the Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup | StartTiles | tileSetting setting to specify the AppID of the app whose tile should appear in a particular position on the Start screen by default.
segment.target: Use the Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup | StartTiles | tileSetting setting to specify the AppID of the app whose tile should appear in a particular position on the Start screen by default.

segment.source: The tile settings follow three naming patterns:
segment.target: The tile settings follow three naming patterns:

segment.source: WideTile and a number from 01 to 06.
segment.target: WideTile and a number from 01 to 06.

segment.source: Each app that you specify for these settings must provide assets, in the app manifest, that provide a wide tile.
segment.target: Each app that you specify for these settings must provide assets, in the app manifest, that provide a wide tile.

segment.source: Each app setting requires that you input the AppID.
segment.target: Each app setting requires that you input the AppID.

segment.source: SquareTile and a number from 01 to 12.
segment.target: SquareTile and a number from 01 to 12.

segment.source: Each app setting requires that you input the AppID.
segment.target: Each app setting requires that you input the AppID.

segment.source: DesktopOrSquareTile and a number from 01 to 06.
segment.target: DesktopOrSquareTile and a number from 01 to 06.

segment.source: For apps in any or all of the DesktopOrSquare settings, you need to specify the appID for the corresponding app, or the path to the desktop app.
segment.target: For apps in any or all of the DesktopOrSquare settings, you need to specify the appID for the corresponding app, or the path to the desktop app.

segment.source: Note If you put an app that supports wide tiles in a square tile spot, the tile is forced to be square instead of wide.
segment.target: Note If you put an app that supports wide tiles in a square tile spot, the tile is forced to be square instead of wide.

segment.source: If you skip a setting, Windows rearranges the flow of app tiles around the app tile position of that setting on the Start screen.
segment.target: If you skip a setting, Windows rearranges the flow of app tiles around the app tile position of that setting on the Start screen.

segment.source: Deploy your Windows image using the modified answer file.
segment.target: Deploy your Windows image using the modified answer file.

segment.source: For more information, see Deploy a Custom Image.
segment.target: For more information, see Deploy a Custom Image.

segment.source: For more information about these settings, see the StartTiles settings topics in the Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup component in the Windows Unattended Setup Reference on TechNet.
segment.target: For more information about these settings, see the StartTiles settings topics in the Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup component in the Windows Unattended Setup Reference on TechNet.
